for most easy and intermediate maps the simplest chimps strat is something like
>triple dart start (can be skipped if you have a cheap hero that can survive until you can drop a ninja)
>hero
>3-0-2 ninja
>3-0-0 alchemist (make sure that only the ninja is in range of the alchemist, if that's not possible put the alchemist as close to the ninja as possible)
>upgrade ninja to 4-0-2
>upgrade alch to 4-0-0
>3-0-2 heli
>2-2-0 village near heli (ideally in range of the hero and ninja too)
>upgrade heli to 5-2-0
>upgrade village to 2-3-0
>0-2-5 spike factory at the end of the track (smart targetting)
>4-2-0 alch near spike factory
this should beat most beginner and intermediate maps on chimps

threads.name: Pretentious Souls Autist
threads.com:
Compared to other FROM titles of the last two generations Elden Ring has very little narrative depth. It has a diagetic and symbolic narrative, yes. But the quality of it is radically inferior compared to most of the other FROM titles of the previous two generations, the gameplay is much less polished, and everything that isn't a legacy dungeon is extremely boring to replay. It gives you the impression that there is depth but when you dig in to look for it it is not there to the extent it is in Dark Souls, Bloodborne, or Sekiro.

FROM games are known for being "mysterious and deep" so normies who like the new FROM game are tripping over themselves to say it's mysterious and deep to get in on the bandwagon of coolness without critically examining the substance of that position. Soulslike is dead, long live Soulslike.

The "good" story telling in Souls games is mostly Ludonarrative Harmony. Really, that's what it comes down to.

Elden Ring's Ludonarrative Harmony is C-. If even. It does some stuff. It does a fraction of what Dark Souls, Bloodborne, and Sekiro do. Elden Ring is not a Gesamtkunstwerk like those titles. Elden Ring is FROM's shot at mass market content and frankly the team seems a little disraught at how successful and critically praised it is. Does Miyazaki look happy in his aware acceptance statement? No, and he asks his fans to continue to have high expectations. He doesn't want his work to become like Marvel Movies and Fortnite.

It's fine for people to like things. It's fine for people to enjoy something without thinking too deeply about it. But Dark Souls and Bloodborne and Sekiro DO have a LOT of narrative depth, and fans were hoping for that again and didn't get it. Elden Ring is a sell out title.

If you think Elden Ring is GOAT you're a dung eater.

Please convince me that Elden Ring is better than I'm giving it credit for.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>620140228
>All your sources are in reference to LED lighting, and domestic lighting has a different definition of white due to the fact that higher temperatures were more difficult to reach.
My sources are from people who manufacture white lights. Yours are in reference to the sRGB standard. D65 is set by taking the color temperature of a white reflector IN DAYLIGHT, i.e. including the scattered blue light from the sky, and skews blue as a result. It is SUPPOSED to skew blue, because it is not supposed to be white, it is supposed to be representative of daylight.

Hence your own source citation:
>CIE standard illuminant D65 should be used in all colorimetric calculations requiring representative daylight
>representative daylight
not white light. Representative daylight. Which skews SLIGHTLY blue because of the increase in blue light due to rayleigh scattering.

None of which matters particularly, because whether or not what we mean by "sunlight" is "pure white" or "pure white that leans slightly bluish", what it emphatically does NOT mean is that "sunlight is yellow". Because it isn't.

As final proof on the matter, I offer this photograph of the sun in the sky. Please note that it is a white fucking ball.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I play competitively, it's a great game.

>Roster It covers nearly every type and a variety of body shapes and popularity levels (shillmons like lucario, pika, zard; popular mons like Gardevoir, Blaziken, Garchomp; more niche favorites like Weavile, Chandelure, Scizor, etc)
>Characters are highly varied in terms of playstyles, both in the sense that two players can play the same character very differently, and that they have varied kits and mechanics (IE braixen and her support cancels/building tools, Aegislash's parry and stance changee mechanic, etc)
>Great balancing, basically every single character is viable in high level play, even characters in low tier still make top 8's all the time
>Mechanics that encourage fundamentals and neutral play where both players are doing mindgames and are trying to get a hit in, such as attack heights functioning as a way for moves to bypass each other and act as reversals, and the 2d-3rd phase, shift see below
>Online is still decently active, community still runs events, stuff is centralized around discord.gg/pokken and the supercombo page

>>620136082
People always say this but, it's a huge part of the competitive depth and why it has such a big neutral emphasis.

At a basic level is acts as an anti-infinite system for the 2d phase; that also forces a return to neutral, with the 3d phase also being an extended buffer layer of neutral (since 3d>2d shifts occur on any heavy hit).

But since different moves add (or even reduce) different points to the PSP guage that dictates when 2d>3d shift happens,; it turns into a resource management and anti-flowcharting system where players alter their combo composition on the fly to do optimum damage without the shift interrupting it or to intentionally go for a less damaging/safe combo route to cause a shift slower (as a sort of reset) or faster depending if that'd be to your advantage or not (EX: would you rather keep them in pressure or get the health/meter from causing shift, etc)
